awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Incorporation of Nano-Sized Diamonds in Advanced Composite Coatings for Reduction of Friction and Wear
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research will attempt to fabricate advanced coatings with reduced friction and wear, as compared to commercially used materials. Tungsten carbide / cobalt coatings are used today in a wide range of sectors including the aerospace, automotive, and energy industries. The incorporation of nano sized diamonds into these materials to form advanced composite coatings is envisioned to improve the wear resistance and reduce friction. The reduction of friction is critically important to improving energy efficiency; for example, it is estimated that 33% of fuel energy in automobiles is consumed in overcoming frictional losses. The proposed research will be conducted at Yonsei University in South Korea in the laboratory of Dr. Dae Eun Kim. The Center for Nano-Wear directed by Dr. Kim has world class facilities for accessing the friction and wear performance of a variety of materials under several types of environments. 

The use of nanodiamonds is expected to address several key concerns in tungsten carbide / cobalt coatings. The wear performance of these coatings is dependent on achieving an optimal combination of strength (e.g. hardness) and ductility (e.g. toughness). These properties are often mutually exclusive as they are dependent on constituent phases which are typically either hard and brittle or soft and tough. The use of diamonds is expected to increase hardness while simultaneously providing toughening by inhibiting the formation of brittle phases. The diamonds are expected to act as a source of carbon during the high temperature processing used to make the coatings, which will inhibit the decarburization of tungsten carbide into brittle phases. Diamond also has excellent thermal conductivity which would be beneficial to wear performance in high temperature environments. Wear tests will be conducted to evaluate the performance under simulated loading conditions and also to elucidate the effects of the nanodiamonds on the material properties.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report (POR)

        This award enabled a successful international collaboration between the principal investigator (PI) and scientists at the Center for NanoWear (CNW) at Yonsei University in South Korea. CNW is a world class center with expertise in the areas of frictional and wear characteristics of metallic, polymeric, and ceramic materials, as well as mutli-scale devices and components. CNW is led by Prof. Dae-Eun Kim who serves on the editorial boards of many international journals on friction and wear. The PI is a doctoral student at the University of California – Davis who is an expert in the areas of nanomaterials, composite science, materials processing, and tribological (e.g. wear/friction) properties. The international travel by the PI enabled a fruitful exchange of information of scientific ideas and methodologies in the areas of expertise of the PI and of the researchers and scientists at CNW. The PI was able to experience the Korean culture in terms of people, technology, and research practices. Aside from the technological contributions of the collaborative project, ties were established that may led to future collaboration between the host university and the PI or home institution. Collaborations between international experts in related fields are critical to maintaining a vibrant and robust progression of science, knowledge, and technology that may yield improvements in educational, academic, and technological infrastructure.  

The collaborative project involved the fabrication of novel ceramic based composite coatings using state of the art facilities available at the PI’s home university, UC Davis. The fabricated composites were then evaluated using the unique facilities available at CNW. The primary characteristics of interest were the frictional and wear properties. Novel composites were compared with commercial used materials in order to gauge the potential impact and technological readiness of the composites developed. This class of materials, cermets, are currently employed in aerospace, automotive, and energy industries. The reduction of friction is critical to reducing part wear and energy losses associated with friction. It is estimated for example, that in a typical automobile, 33% of fuel energy is consumed in overcoming frictional losses associated with moving parts in contact. This fact demonstrates how reducing frictional losses can lead to improvements in performance and energy efficiency.

The novelty of the proposed work primarily entailed the incorporation of nanometric diamonds in order to enhance the wear resistance of ceramic based coatings. The utilization of nanometric particle offers promising advantages such as the ability to simultaneous provide strength and ductility. The fabrication of materials with nanometric particles is inherently challenging because of strong adhesive forces present between nano-particles that can cause them to cluster together, thereby hindering their effectiveness. Fabrication was carried out at UC Davis and composites were characterized at both UC Davis and CNW. The frictional and wear characteristics of nanocomposite were compared with commercially used tungsten carbide / cobalt cermet coatings by conducting simulated frictional wear tests at CNW. A mechanistic investigation on the role of nanometric diamonds on the wear performance of composites was conducted at CNW and UC Davis in order to guide future efforts in designing and fabricating nano-diamond based composites that exhibit enhanced wear resistance and frictional behavior. The development of such composite materials may enable potential savings in energy consumption and/or enhanced system performance in the automotive, aerospace, and energy industries that utilize ceramic based coatings. The results of performance tests and the sc...

Project Outcomes Report (POR)

        This award enabled a successful international collaboration between the principal investigator (PI) and scientists at the Center for NanoWear (CNW) at Yonsei University in South Korea. CNW is a world class center with expertise in the areas of frictional and wear characteristics of metallic, polymeric, and ceramic materials, as well as mutli-scale devices and components. CNW is led by Prof. Dae-Eun Kim who serves on the editorial boards of many international journals on friction and wear. The PI is a doctoral student at the University of California – Davis who is an expert in the areas of nanomaterials, composite science, materials processing, and tribological (e.g. wear/friction) properties. The international travel by the PI enabled a fruitful exchange of information of scientific ideas and methodologies in the areas of expertise of the PI and of the researchers and scientists at CNW. The PI was able to experience the Korean culture in terms of people, technology, and research practices. Aside from the technological contributions of the collaborative project, ties were established that may led to future collaboration between the host university and the PI or home institution. Collaborations between international experts in related fields are critical to maintaining a vibrant and robust progression of science, knowledge, and technology that may yield improvements in educational, academic, and technological infrastructure.  

The collaborative project involved the fabrication of novel ceramic based composite coatings using state of the art facilities available at the PIÆs home university, UC Davis. The fabricated composites were then evaluated using the unique facilities available at CNW. The primary characteristics of interest were the frictional and wear properties. Novel composites were compared with commercial used materials in order to gauge the potential impact and technological readiness of the composites developed. This class of materials, cermets, are currently employed in aerospace, automotive, and energy industries. The reduction of friction is critical to reducing part wear and energy losses associated with friction. It is estimated for example, that in a typical automobile, 33% of fuel energy is consumed in overcoming frictional losses associated with moving parts in contact. This fact demonstrates how reducing frictional losses can lead to improvements in performance and energy efficiency.

The novelty of the proposed work primarily entailed the incorporation of nanometric diamonds in order to enhance the wear resistance of ceramic based coatings. The utilization of nanometric particle offers promising advantages such as the ability to simultaneous provide strength and ductility. The fabrication of materials with nanometric particles is inherently challenging because of strong adhesive forces present between nano-particles that can cause them to cluster together, thereby hindering their effectiveness. Fabrication was carried out at UC Davis and composites were characterized at both UC Davis and CNW. The frictional and wear characteristics of nanocomposite were compared with commercially used tungsten carbide / cobalt cermet coatings by conducting simulated frictional wear tests at CNW. A mechanistic investigation on the role of nanometric diamonds on the wear performance of composites was conducted at CNW and UC Davis in order to guide future efforts in designing and fabricating nano-diamond based composites that exhibit enhanced wear resistance and frictional behavior. The development of such composite materials may enable potential savings in energy consumption and/or enhanced system performance in the automotive, aerospace, and energy industries that utilize ceramic based coatings. The results of performance tests and the scientific investigations on the role of nanometric diamonds on cermet coatings are already under peer review. The findings enabled by this award...
